byline.contributor: Aaron E. Carroll is a professor of pediatrics at Indiana University School of Medicine. He blogs on health research and policy at The Incidental Economist, and you can follow him on Twitter at @aaronecarroll.

abstract: The Upshot; research indicates that artificial sweeteners do not deserve the bad reputation they have acquired over the years, and that they present far healthier option than sugar; notoriety of sugar substitutes can be traced to single study linking saccharin to cancer, which cemented opinions despite fact that substance is no longer considered a carcinogen.
lead_paragraph: Added sugar is bad for your health, studies indicate, while sugar substitutes do not deserve the bad reputation they have acquired.

headline.main: The Evidence Supports Artificial Sweeteners Over Sugar
headline.print_headline: If You Drink Soda, Choose Artificially Sweetened

snippet: Added sugar is bad for your health, studies indicate, while sugar substitutes do not deserve the bad reputation they have acquired.
